oai_set_ssi: pch||Pope County Historical Society||The Pope County Historical Society in Glenwood, Minnesota, collects photographs, printed materials and artifacts related to the history of Pope County. The historical society's contribution to Minnesota Reflections features the work of M.J. Trenham, a portrait and landscape photographer from Alexandria, Minnesota. Subjects include businesses, residences and town scenes.
collection_description_tesi: The Pope County Historical Society in Glenwood, Minnesota, collects photographs, printed materials and artifacts related to the history of Pope County. The historical society's contribution to Minnesota Reflections features the work of M.J. Trenham, a portrait and landscape photographer from Alexandria, Minnesota. Subjects include businesses, residences and town scenes.
transcription_tesi:
POWERLINE PROTEST NEWSLETTER* *»PRES S RELEASE     OCT, 1Q-NOV, 5.
' COURT CAPERS. '
We have 2 court appearances this week, with Tom Marthaler coming up on
Tuesday, November 7th in St0 Cloud and the Delano 20 starting their trial in
Buffalo on Wednesday, November 8th,
Tom's appearing on the charge of, and are you ready for this, "Possession of Illegal Police Monitoring Equipment", stemming from an incident last
July 8th v/hen he was rudely interrupted at work by a bunch of laWenforcement
types. Proceedings.will start at id::06am«
Then there's the Delano 20. In case you haven't been following this
series of events, it's gone something like this...
Last Monday, October 30th, the 19 people arrested at Delano" (having already begun their hunger strike) were arraigned in Buffalo** (Our 15 year old
freedom fighter, who v/as also arrested, was released on'Sunday). Bail v/as
set at $500 for 15 and $1000 for the %  others. The reasoning of the prosecutor was that two of the people-were from out of state (evon though one wasn't)
and that the other 2 were "leaders" and had "promised them that it was going
to be a peaceful demonstration and had lied." Well, needless to say, everyone decided to stay in and protest the excessive bail.
On Tuesday, Lawyer Ken Tillsen from the Legal Defense/Offense Comiiu went
to Buffalo with about 30 folks from the cities and 7 or so from out our Waya
Ken got the bail lowered to "'300 for everyone and also arranged for one Wright-
Co, resident v/ho was busted to get PCR„ By this time many organizations were
calling in and offering to put up bail, so the decision was made that 8 of
the remaining 18 v/ho had job committments and the like, would bail out and
the remaining 10 would stay in until they.either got P«R. or went to trial.
Under the law, you can only hold people for so long before they are entitled
to a speedy trial within 10 daysv
So, starting Wednesday morning the Delano 20 v/ill be stating their case
in front of a jury. The minor who was arrested will be receiving a court
date soon for juvenile proceedings. More on the Delano 20 later.
The other item on Court Capers this week concerns folks with indictments,.
Some of the "indictees" have had their bail returned in the last week. If
you've had your bail returned or are wondering where it is, call Deborah Pick
at 283-5428. Other than that, lawyers have been set up to cover all the indictment cases and we're just sitting tight till v/e hear from Tom Thumb.
Coming upj_ The Villard 3's omnibus hearing on December 5th,
**********************
# There will be a meeting in Belle Plaine
*
*
# Nov. 16th at 8:00pm being sponsored by #
# a group of protesting farmers called   #
# the Landowners-Association. It will be  t
held at the same locale as the last.mtng
and everyone is.welcome to come and
show their support.

IHAT GOES UK. .MUST COME DOWN
Traverse and Grant are losing insulators, Pope is getting imported cops on
the weekends, Stearns and Meeker'have condemnation hearings with their commissioners coming up and Wright Co. jail is getting cables from Paris and
Berlin! But the big thing again.this week is people having trouble with T.V.'
radios, and phones as v/e11 as with their health when the line is juiced. So
let's keep phoning in those complaints to:
1) Your local telephone company.
2) Rey Rahko, -project coordinator UPA, 441-312i»
3) KCMT ToV., 766-5166,
4) 800-442-3013oC.the powerline HOTLINE.
